We (city, advocates, etc.) seriously need to hear your concerns. So make sure you're speaking them and doing so as someone who lives there.
And when speaking those concerns, my advice is to get to the root of it – too many cars. What can be done to discourage cut-through?
And as advocates and people who can execute your ideas, isn't it incumbent to consider all data?
There are simple fixes. There's no traffic control coming off Pershing/Nicholson to head East on Culver. Why wasn't this addressed?
You now have multiple lanes trying to merge with three lights in a half mile. Abysmal planning. Why?
I understand a holistic, multi-disciplinary approach, but you have major arteries (105 East at 405 interchange, for one) under construction.

That forces people to turn to their "cut-throughs."

The idea here might be sound, but the execution is costing people their lives.
This street literally cost people their lives before any changes were made.
And I genuinely appreciate that. But to take this to the logical extreme, your solution would be four-way stops at every intersection.
Good thing is, changes can be piloted, tested, analyzed, reviewed, and adjusted with real data.
There is a balance. Safety is paramount, yet there are other considerations. This is an overreaction, as I see it.

And real lives are affected in that time. That's what you're glossing over.

I am a data-driven person. I get it. This gives data a bad name

It would seem marginal changes over time give one a chance to iterate and reiterate, not drastic, overnight modification.
